9. A more transparent healthcare system would help people understand costs and make better decisions.
10. Health insurance costs should be income-based to make them more affordable for lower-income individuals.
11. Higher out-of-pocket payments would prevent excessive use of healthcare services.
12. As health insurance premiums rise, more households require financial assistance, such as individual premium subsidies, to afford coverage.
13. Reducing bureaucratic inefficiencies and simplifying administrative processes in healthcare could lead to significant cost savings.
14. The current system encourages excessive use of services once the deductible ('franchise') has been paid, leading to unnecessary treatments and higher overall costs.
15. A public single-payer health insurance system would reduce administrative and marketing costs, making the healthcare system more affordable overall.
16. Government control of drug prices would prevent pharmaceutical companies from charging excessive prices.
17. Income-based health insurance contributions would make insurance fairer for low-income individuals.
18. The increasing demand for healthcare services is mainly due to an aging population that requires more medical care.
19. Hospitals are more interested in maximizing their profits than in ensuring quality and access to healthcare.
20. Switzerland currently has a 'two-tier' healthcare system, where wealthier individuals receive better healthcare than others.
21. Better coordination between primary care, hospitals, and specialists is essential for the effective treatment of chronic diseases.
22. It is important to involve more private actors in healthcare (e.g., outsourcing administrative tasks in hospitals to specialized companies) to reduce costs.
23. More competition in mandatory health insurance, where insurers can offer alternative models, would promote innovation and efficiency in healthcare.
24. Abolishing mandatory health insurance would reduce the financial burden on households.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 49 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 49 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 49 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. People should be told if commercial companies could get access to their samples and information.
2. Biobanks are valuable because they promise huge benefits for our economy.
3. It is acceptable for samples and information that doesn't identify me to be sent to researchers overseas.
4. I do not mind if researchers have access to my samples, when there is no way I can be identified.
5. There must be special consideration of the views of Aboriginal people towards healthcare and genetic research.
6. Policy makers need to consider whether WA should not have biobanks.
7. It is always acceptable to do research on samples that identify me, without my prior permission.
8. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for in the future bothers me.
9. I should be asked for my permission every time researchers want to use my samples for research
10. Biobanks are valuable even if they only advance science (e.g. provide new information about diseases) and do not lead to treatments or cures.
11. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health in other ways.
12. It's OK if data that identifies me is stored in a separate database and replaced in the biobank by a unique non-identifying code.
13. People should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at any time.
14. People should be paid for providing their samples to a biobank.
15. I should have property rights to my tissues before and after they leave my body
16. We should all provide samples to biobanks because it will benefit everyone.
17. Genetic research will improve our lives.
18. Researchers and institutions (e.g. hospitals and universities) should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.
19. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.
20. I do not mind if my sample is connected to my name and medical information.
21. Commercial companies should keep all the profits they make from biobanking because they take the financial risks and put up the money to develop new drugs and treatments.
22. There is no risk to the people who provide samples and information to biobanks.
23. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
24. I don't mind if my samples are connected to my medical records without my prior permission, so long as researchers don't get access to any data that identifies me.
25. Genetic studies of race on ethnic or cultural groups will lead to the discrimination of those groups.
26. I trust researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
27. Commercial companies should get access to biobanks, otherwise new drugs and treatments will not be developed.
28. Biobanks will only lead to high profits and expensive treatments that most people can't afford.
29. The priorities for health should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.
30. Information about people's genes and the traits they inherit from their parents is more private than their medical records.
31. The public will be more protected if biobanks are government-funded not privately funded.
32. Genetic studies will lead to the discrimination of people living with genetic conditions or disabilities.
33. People who provide samples for research should get special access to the treatments that result from this research.
34. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies
35. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
36. Improved health is more likely to come from educating people about their diet and lifestyle than from biobanks.
37. The community that provides samples for research should receive improved medical services in return.
38. Biobanks need to be monitored and reviewed by external, independent people to prevent the misuse of data and samples.
39. I trust independent research ethics committees, which are not connected to the biobank in anyway, to decide whether research is ethical and approve who gets access to my samples.
40. Religious groups need to be asked for their views about biobanks and genetic research.
41. My sample should never be permanently anonymized since I should be contacted about important research results
42. There is no point asking the public for their views on the ethical issues in science and technology.
43. I trust biobanks with managers who are independent of researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
44. Collecting samples from people in an ethnic or cultural group is acceptable only if the whole group has agreed to participate.
45. People with a [chronic disease or] genetic condition in their family have a responsibility to be involved in genetic research.
46. People who provide samples should be active in the set up and ongoing management of biobanks.
47. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government.
48. The biobank owner should be able to sell any information they have about my genes, if they want to.
49. Profits from biobanking should be shared in some way with the community who provided the samples.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Privately Funded with minimal regulation: Minimal regulation of privately run biobanking system with maximum participation of the public. Low privacy provisions.
2. Cautious Implementation: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Very strict oversight of use of biobanks and strong privacy provisions.
3. Privately Funded with strong regulation: A BB system where funding is provided mostly by private companies, withstrong government oversight and privacy provisions.
4. Minimal Government Input: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Fairly relaxed oversight of use of biobanks and  privacy provisions (low level of regulation).
5. Publicly Funded with minimal regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
6. Publicly Funded with strong regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
7. High Privacy: Implementation of a (publicy or privately owned) biobanking system where privacy of individuals is paramount. Stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individual donors.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I value strong regulation and privacy, preferably in a publicly funded system.

1. Street scene in Uppsala has changed for the worse since the beggars have come.
2. Sweden can not take responsibility for all the poor people in the world.
3. Many beggars are victims.
4. Beggars should not bring their children to Sweden but leave them at home so they can attend school.
5. EU migrants coming to Uppsala due to rumors of more support and shelter for the homeless.
6. The beggars trying to cheat me out of money by playing sick and poor even though they are not.
7. If we begin to help those who come here to beg for it will soon be even more.
8. We need to focus on giving them help in their homeland.
9. Before we assist foreign beggars, we must take care of our own Swedish homeless.
10. The beggars have it good here in Sweden and would rather live here. 
11. Home countries Romania and Bulgaria have a responsibility to improve the situation of their minority population.
12. Beggars can get away with things that you and I would not get away with.
13. The migrant beggars are eating way the Swedish welfare state
14. They should look for jobs instead of begging.
15. Beggars have the same values as us and therefore we have an obligation to help them with school, work, housing and food.
16. Politicians in Uppsala take no responsibility for the beggars.
17. We should take in more refugees in Sweden.
18. I have no responsibility for helping the begging Roma in Sweden.
19. It is our establishment which invites them to beg and take part of our social safety net.
20. The EU is responsible to handle the situation involving EU citizens crossing borders to beg.
21. The EU is powerless against Romania's shameless treatment of the Roma minority.
22. It's good to give money to the beggars
23. We must improve the beggars conditions when they are in Sweden.
24. The emergence of "parallel societies" and "slums" in Uppsala, is not acceptable.
25. The municipality is responsible for helping the begging EU citizens in Sweden.
26. Allowing street begging in some EU countries, including Sweden, does not facilitate Romania's efforts to achieve social inclusion and enhancing employability
27. Begging EU Citizens really want to go back to their country and not live in Sweden.
28. It is not OK to break Swedish law just because the offenders are poor.
29. Our tax money should go to the Swedes not to foreign beggars.
30. Begging on the streets of Uppsala is organized with connections to the criminal mafia.
31. I feel guilty that I have it good when I see a beggar.
32. Why don't we just treat the beggars the same as we do refugees? They are in the same situation.
33. Begging is caused by poverty and discrimination of minority groups in certain EU countries.
34. We can not help so much that we are sending the wrong signals.
35. I feel helpless when I see a beggar.
36. Beggars are victims of poverty in their home countries.
37.  Romania is failing to take responsibility for the Roma population.
38. Tourism in Sweden is damaged when the image of a clean and safe country no longer proves correct.
39. We should try the beggars to find other ways to help themselves.
40. There are too many beggars on the streets of Uppsala.
41. There is no ultimate responsibility for begging EU citizens.
42. The Swedish state is responsible for helping the begging Roma in Sweden.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.

2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

1. Forbid giving money to beggars
2. Provide accommodation for beggars (more)
3. Ban Illegal Settlements
4. Enforce existing laws without special consideration for beggars
5. Ban Begging within Sweden
6. Focus resources on addressing the the problem in source countries such as Romania
7. Deport any immigrants found begging on the streets who have stayed in Sweden longer than three months

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I believe in addressing the root cause of begging in source countries and providing local support.

1. Not voting is a form of expression. It's a way of telling parties that no one is offering policies that appeal to you.
2. Proportional Representation also forces parties to coalesce and moderates out the extreme political views. 
3. We suffer a Parliamentary Democracy and an archaic and conflict oriented, "two party system" where one of two main parties will manipulate us for the next few years. 
4. In the Senate there should be elected representatives who are not from the major parties but from smaller interest groups.
5. There is a lot of consultation by govt – but who is listening?  And what power do they have to make changes?
6. People get the government they deserve
7. The only time we are all equal is when we vote in the ballot box.

9. In Australia the rich have virtually unlimited access to the legal system and the capacity to use it to achieve their own ends.
10. We live in a great democracy.

15. Democracy is a term which has lost much of its original meaning.
16. Democracy means that all policy is exposed to open discussion and debate in a public political space of all citizens before being put to a transparent, accountable vote.
17. Democracy means we, the people, are responsible for what government does, or fails to do.
18. We are a democratic country.
19. Until women are equally represented in Australian parliaments, we will not have a genuine representative democracy.
20. People are quite capable of processing and thinking about the vast majority of issues facing our society but as long as we are subjected to 'news lite' the level of political debate will remain facile. 
21. The fundamental dynamic of Australian society is that it is one of evolution, not revolution.
22. I suppose we do have an upper class and a lower class.
23. If you want your vote to count for anything, then you need to not vote in ignorance, you need to know something about what you're being offered.
24. Low female participation rates compound the domination of the public realm by males.
25. I'm always cynical about government processes.
26. A lot of people may be politically ignorant, but they believe what they see and hear on television, and that makes them vote the way they do. They have been brainwashed by the clever advertising people.
27. Too few people have a lot of sway in the system.  Corporate lobbyists, vested interests, pork barrelling and contributions to political parties are all problematic.
28. I don't think we have a lot of input into legislation and a lot of things that are important.
29. There's a dollar democracy that runs through our supposed democracy.
30. You don't have to wait three years to say 'I'm not happy with the job you did.' You can apply pressure, and enough people writing to the local member can turn the situation around.
31. The people we elect are loyal not to we dumb bunnies who elected them, but the agenda and dogma of their party. 
32. The true believers are about decency in life, about a capacity to debate the issues and to receive different views.
33. The true function of government is to maintain peace and justice. This does not include interfering in private transactions of its electors.
34. The party system is the main obstruction to accountable politics.
35. Free markets work because individual people, cooperating peacefully and voluntarily through markets, can achieve much that politicians and bureaucrats cannot achieve using compulsion and direction.
36. It would be a great thing if voters could vote on specific issues, not only on a whole party program at election time.
37. Our government is attempting to mould our society to the needs of a profit-oriented market
38. Our political system's strength is that it can change to meet changing circumstances.
39. Our community and nation should invoke a spirit that you are important, that you do have a way of influencing things.
40. We as individuals have a right, that's what democracy means to me
41. I don't know too much about democracy. I feel ridiculous voting.
42. Governments can talk a great game about 'democracy'. They fall down, in practice, because they cannot accept any sharing of the power to influence decisions with those who might have different motives and ideas.
43. I don't want to be in a place where only a minority's viewpoint gets the right to say what's going to happen.

1. When I read in the paper that climate change is not true, I start to have doubts about whether it is changing.
2. Climate variation is normal, so why should this be a problem?
3. The response to  climate change is not going to be positive.  The same mistakes will keep happening.
4. If Australia reduces greenhouse gases it won't make a difference. That will just shift Australian jobs to other countries. 
5. Climate change will not be a problem because there will be technological solutions available.
6. It is already too late to do anything, as any action to stop climate change will take a long time to take effect.
7. Australia's emissions are tiny, so it's not up to us to act.
8. The fate of the planet is too important to be left to market forces.
9. It's difficult to trust what comes out in the media on the issue of climate change.
10. We should pay for greenhouse emissions.
11. More educational programmes are needed to increase public awareness about climate change.
12. Doing something to reduce emissions feels a bit hopeless but I just want to feel that I'm doing the most I can.
13. There's not much point in me doing anything to fix this. No-one else is going to.
14. I care about the planet.
15. We need strong political leadership to do something about climate change.
16. I don't trust what scientists say about climate change.
17. I'm not going to do anything to address climate change because it is not a major issue.
18. Governments should take a far greater role in preparing towns and cities to adapt to the impacts of climate change.
19. This is so depressing and is so out of our control.
20. I want to do something, but it is too big and too hard.
21. It is unfair that we are going to leave the climate in a mess for future generations.
22. I don't trust what I hear about climate change from government.
23. We can adapt to the coming changes.
24. Failure to address climate change is the fault of political leaders.
25. We need laws addressing climate change because people are not going to volunteer to change.
26. I believe that the difference we can have as an individual, in Australia, is so minimal that our actions are worthless.
27. I don't know what to do. I'm very concerned and would like to do something, but I don't have a realistic shortlist of things that would really make a difference.
28. Australia does not owe it to the rest of the world to reduce emissions and suffer economically.
29. I think it is safe to say climate change is here.
30. There is not enough information to definitively say that climate change is real.
31. It is clear that we are already entering the zone of dangerous climate change.
32. I'm not concerned enough to do anything drastic about this, such as participate in political action.
33. Australia is particularly vulnerable to climate change, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Aggressive fire suppression has caused the majority of the problems regarding  fires. 
2. People should take what is needed from forests, but in a context of stewardship and sustainable use and interaction with nature. 
3. Forest lands should be brought back to their state before human intervention began.
4. Environmental organizations have moved the management of our forests to where it is being done by emotion and not by science.
5. Thinning efforts should focus entirely on the small trees that make up the vast majority of the fire risk in the forest. 
6. We need to clean up the bureaucratic maze that stops our professional foresters from being able to do the work that they are trained to do.
7. We need to experiment with a range of treatments that could meet restoration goals. 
8. We have to move forward with large-scale restoration-based fuel reduction and learn as we go.
9. All fuels treatment projects on public lands should comply with existing environmental laws even if compliance slows implementation.
10. If an action is determined to be necessary to control a wildfire, save lives and/or property, and ensure that fire crews can do their jobs safely and efficiently, then it is appropriate to act even if it results in the take of an endangered species.
11. We need to be cautious: the solution is there, but we still have a lot to learn. If we just jump in, we're going to make mistakes.
12. Prescribed burning is needed to restore fire-adapted ecosystems.
13. Prescribed burns are a flawed idea, especially when there are other practices available for restoration.
14. We need active forest management on our public lands, through thinning and prescribed burns to reduce the unnatural buildup of fuels.
15. Old Growth protection is necessary in order to preserve and protect the viability of species dependent upon Old Growth ecosystems.
16. The government is advancing timber sales in the name of ecological restoration.
17. Federal land management procedures are so complex that they prevent timely action to address ecological crises on public lands.
18. To make thinning projects cost effective, private logging companies must be able to log larger trees.
19. Fire is a natural and vital component of most western forest ecosystems.
20. Using citizen participation in forest management is very important for basing decisions on different ideas and cultural values along with science. 
21. The increased density of forests in the West has not damaged ecosystems.
22. Returning forests to presettlement conditions ignores the need for wildlife that are adapted to current forest conditions by mandating drastic thinning virtually overnight. 
23. Small scale thinning projects should give the communities involved pride in taking part in a sustainable forest management plan, and it also allows the traditional communities to realize a boost to their fragile economies.
24. A diameter cap should be placed on all thinning projects to ensure large trees are not cut.
25. Forest restoration projects should be done in all areas of the forest including roadless and wilderness areas.
26. Natural resources must be developed for the benefit of the plain American citizen.
27. Federal agencies need to restore public trust through transparency in project intent, development and implementation.
28. Large trees must be removed in order to create openings for wildlife habitat. 
29. Forest health needs restoring after decades of government mismanagement.
30. Humans are a part of the environment. We need to learn how to live sustainably with that environment as much as possible. 
31. We need to allow forest managers to determine how to improve forest health to minimize fire damage and loss.
32. Stakeholders in forest management should work together to define management objectives more by experiments and adaptive management. 
33. Land managers should return public forest land to natural conditions and fire cycles that are specific to each forest-type.
34. Federal forest management policy should make it easier for loggers to thin out backcountry forests by easing regulatory restrictions and making it harder for interest groups to stop or delay that work.
35. Needless red tape and lawsuits delay effective implementation of forest health projects on public lands.
36. Forest management involves restoring ecosystem function and processes that maintain ecosystems over the long run. 
37. The main issue in forest management is to protect loss of life and property due to catastrophic wildfire. 
38. Without public participation there will be conflict, whereas participation leads to cooperation.
39. We should not manipulate nature by restoring forest conditions.
40. Demonizing fire is a mistake: we must accept risks of fire damage to property and implement controlled burning.
41. Traditional, sustainable forestry that benefits local economies and maintains rural livelihoods is much better than large scale corporate forestry.
42. Fire risk reduction projects should clearly focus on the wildland-urban interface, avoiding treatments in roadless areas.
43. Forests must contribute to the economic stability of forest-dependent communities.  There are many job opportunities and value-added products that come out of the forest such as wood for art, vigas for building homes, wildlife for food, herbs for medicine, and grass for livestock.
44. Science is the most important component informing all management decisions — more so than social, cultural and economic considerations.
45. Forest health means jobs.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Management that favors thinning treatments to realize economic gain.
2. Management that favors treatments to restore structure, function and composition of the forest to presettlement conditions, and allowing the introduction of fire as a natural disturbance.
3. Management that favors local-based harvesting for fuel and timber needs.
4. Management that prioritizes the location and level of treatments favoring both ecological and social values (i.e. wildlife, watersheds, community protection, special cultural places).
5. No fire or fuels management. Leaving the forests as they stand without active management.
6. Management that favors the protection of wildlife and wildlife habitat.
7. Management that favors aggressive reduction of hazardous fuels

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritize ecological restoration, local harvesting, and wildlife protection over economic gain.

33. Returning forests to presettlement conditions ignores the need for wildlife that are adapted to current forest conditions by mandating drastic thinning virtually overnight. 
34. Forest lands should be brought back to their state before human intervention began.
35. Science is the most important component informing all management decisions — more so than social, cultural and economic considerations.
36. A diameter cap should be placed on all thinning projects to ensure large trees are not cut.
37. The government is advancing timber sales in the name of ecological restoration.
38. Traditional, sustainable forestry that benefits local economies and maintains rural livelihoods is much better than large scale corporate forestry.
39. The increased density of forests in the West has not damaged ecosystems.
40. To make thinning projects cost effective, private logging companies must be able to log larger trees.
41. The main issue in forest management is to protect loss of life and property due to catastrophic wildfire. 
42. We have to move forward with large-scale restoration-based fuel reduction and learn as we go.
43. We need to be cautious: the solution is there, but we still have a lot to learn. If we just jump in, we're going to make mistakes.
44. We need to allow forest managers to determine how to improve forest health to minimize fire damage and loss.
45. Environmental organizations have moved the management of our forests to where it is being done by emotion and not by science.

3. There is not enough information to definitively say that climate change is real.

12. There is no urgent need to prepare for an increase in illness and death caused by high temperatures.

14. We need to focus on adaptation actions that are concerned with the economic future of the country.
15. I think it is safe to say climate change is here.
16. Switzerland is particularly vulnerable to climate change, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.
17. Occorre tenere conto degli effetti negativi del cambiamento climatico sul commercio locale.
18. It is NOT necessary to engage with the community when deciding what are the most important issues for planning for climate adaptation.

20. Some communities will be more affected than others by climate change, but this is not a priority issue.

## Instructions:

- In your response, return an ordered list of 32 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Some countries or regions of the world will be more affected by climate change than others, but this is not our top priority.
2. Climate change is primarily caused by human activity.
3. It is certain to say that climate change exists.
4. I believe that the impact we can achieve as individuals in Switzerland is so small that our actions are useless.
5. Doing something to reduce emissions seems a bit hopeless to me, but I just want to feel like I'm doing my best.
6. We should focus on protecting human systems rather than protecting ecosystems.
7. Planning climate change response measures requires a global approach that considers a wide range of interventions rather than specific individual actions.
8. We need to take into account the negative effects of climate change on local businesses.
9. It is difficult to trust government reports on climate change.
10. Authorities have the resources they need to effectively adapt to climate change.
11. There is not enough information to conclusively say that climate change is real.
12. Health systems must prepare for both the physical health impacts of climate change (e.g., heat stroke) and the mental health impacts (e.g., farmers losing their crops).
13. The planning of measures to tackle climate change should focus primarily on extreme weather events such as droughts and floods.
14. Climate change is natural; there is no need to worry.
15. Authorities should receive additional funding to strengthen measures against emergencies and weather-related disasters such as floods.
16. Rising insurance costs are a serious problem related to climate change.
17. It is difficult to trust what the media report about climate change.
18. It is NOT necessary to involve society in deciding which key issues are important for climate change adaptation planning.
19. There is no urgent need to prepare for an increase in illnesses and deaths caused by high temperatures.
20. It is difficult to trust scientists' reports on climate change.
21. It is important to prepare for the migration of people displaced by the effects of climate change.
22. The melting of Alpine glaciers is not a real problem for our daily lives.
23. It doesn't make much sense for me to do anything to solve the problem. No one else is doing anything.
24. It is important to support vulnerable groups (the elderly, children, people with disabilities, low-income individuals) as they have fewer resources to deal with the impacts of climate change.
25. The urban heat island effect must be tackled with measures such as planting trees.
26. I'm not going to do anything about climate change because it's not an important issue.
27. It is important to focus on adaptation measures that take into account the country's economic future.
28. Even if Switzerland were to reduce all its CO₂ emissions, global warming would continue.
29. Society should be included in the discussion on climate change adaptation.
30. I don't know what to do. I am very worried and would like to do something, but I don't have a realistic set of actions that would truly make a difference.
31. It is necessary to have strong on-the-ground disaster response capabilities to deal with extreme weather conditions.
32. Switzerland is particularly vulnerable to climate change, and it is in our interest to contribute to an effective global solution.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Policies that emphasise economic growth over climate change adaptation or mitigation.
2. "Policies that involve a moderate reduction in CO₂ emissions (e.g., reducing emissions by 25% to 50% over the next 10 years)."
3. "Policies that involve a radical reduction in CO₂ emissions (e.g., reducing emissions by 50% to 100% over the next 10 years)."
4. Adaptation policies and expenditure. Planning controls and emergency response programs.
5. Adaptation policies that target individual, small business or community-based actions (e.g., support the installation of alternative energy generators, insulation, water use efficiency)
6. Leave the policy settings as they are.
7. Preparing for climate risk through the development of new approaches and technologies that enhance resilience to the impacts of climate variability or change.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritize adaptation and moderate emission reduction over economic growth or status quo.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 36 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- Using the Q Methodology, rate the statements following a Fixed Quasi-Normal Distribution between 1 and 11.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 36 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 36 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Any changes to the bridge should give right consideration to the environment.bridge
2. Providing a better pedestrian and cycle traffic should be the main consideration when deciding about the future of the bridge.
3. The most important issue for cyclists is safety, which means they need access across the bridge which has a good surface.
4. Replacing timber elements with steel components would destroy the authentic appearance of the bridge.
5. The main concern is to have a bridge that underpins the economic activities in the region.
6. The old bridge provides a scenic entrance to Fremantle that attracts tourists.
7. Whatever works are undertaken, the heritage value of the old bridge will be affected.
8. Since the traffic bridge has important heritage significance, the only grounds for its removal should be on the grounds of serious safety issues and verified by heritage engineers.
9. The critical infrastructure of the bridge raises serious safety concerns. 
10. When deciding about the future of the bridge, indigenous concerns should be given adequate consideration. 
11. It is most important that the solution is a long term one.
12. Altering or replacing the existing Fremantle Bridge means diminishing Fremantle.
13. The cost of maintaining the old timber structure is too high.
14. The Fremantle Traffic Bridge is the most iconic landmark and the main tourist attraction in Fremantle. 
15. We should definitely preserve the heritage value of the bridge, but only if it is financially viable.
16. The function of the Fremantle Bridge as a transport gateway is more important than its heritage.
17. The existing bridge is too low; archways too narrow and do not line up with the railway bridge making navigation dangerous. 
18. The Fremantle Bridge is irreplaceable. It is a strong, enduring part of our history.
19. The bridge is certainly an attractive entry statement to Fremantle and without doubt far more important than trucks.
20. We just got traffic calming in Town Centre after 25 years effort. I don't want bridge to be build bigger, better faster to reverse the gains of the last 25 years.
21. The bridge has stood the test of time for the past 67 years; there's no need for major changes to it.
22. The safety of the bridge is more important than its appearance.
23. The problem is not the vulnerable structure of the bridge but excessive traffic, which should be reduced.
24. Tax payers money should be spent on services that are more essential than upgrading the bridge.
25. River craft deserve better traffic conditions on the Swan River.
26. The old bridge will never be able to handle vehicles, bike and pedestrians at the same time.
27. We shouldn't stick to the past when deciding about the future of the bridge, we should be open for modern design options.
28. Indigenous people would want to minimize impact on the Swan River, a registered site, that is of importance and significance to them.
29. Reducing the risk of vessel collision on the Swan River should be the main consideration when deciding about the future of the bridge
30. This magnificent timber bridge is a rare and beautiful sight in today's world, it should be preserved. 
31. The most important thing is that access to Fremantle from its north is maintained in the most undisturbed manner as possible. 
32. Safe and efficient movement of all road and river users across and under the bridge should the main considerations
33. Alterations will lead to nothing but the uglification of the bridge.
34. It is worth spending money to retain the iconic status of the bridge.
35. As long as there is a bridge that I can cross, I don't care about its structure.
36. There are no specific economic benefits for the Fremantle from the bridge.

2. Construct a new standard bridge next to the current bridge, leaving a section of the existing bridge as a heritage and recreation site
3. Retain existing bridge, but replace the navigation spans and deteriorated components and incorporate bridge widening
4. Construct a new standard bridge and retain the existing bridge as a pedestrian/cyclist facility
5. Construct a new bridge that is a major entry statements for Fremantle, leaving a section of the existing bridge as a heritage recreation site

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 20 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 20 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 20 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Personal cultural or religious beliefs and preferences should guide the choice of treatment methods, including therapy and medication.
2. Mental health problems are solely medical in nature and not a social issue.
3. Mental health can be understood in different ways. A comprehensive definition of mental health should take into account social issues such as poverty, inequality, and discrimination.
4. Personal solutions (such as joining a yoga club) are more effective than government intervention in addressing mental health issues (such as having social workers or psychologists in schools).
5. To prevent people with mental health issues from feeling lonely or isolated, we should talk more about these topics in schools and workplaces to increase public understanding and sensitivity.
6. Private mental health services are better than public ones, so Switzerland's mental health system should be entirely privatized.
7. Social media platforms should be required to have parental controls.
8. Investing in mental health services in schools and workplaces (for example, having social workers in facilities) is essential to prevent negative mental health outcomes.
9. It is good that basic health insurance does not fully cover mental health care since only a few people need it.
10. People with mental disorders should not be allowed to work with children.
11. More government funding is needed to improve mental health services and their accessibility, especially for marginalized people subject to socioeconomic disparities.
12. Minors under the age of 16 should be legally prohibited from using social media.
13. Focusing on prevention strategies (e.g., government media campaigns) is essential to reducing the impact of stigma associated with mental health conditions.
14. Mental health issues require less urgency and fewer resources compared to physical health conditions.
15. Improving working or study conditions does not impact people's mental health in any way.
16. People should take responsibility for actively addressing their own biases and prejudices against individuals with mental health disorders.
17. Social media contribute to mental health issues through cyberbullying, social comparison, and unrealistic portrayals of life.
18. Being poor, living far from urban centers, or being a victim of racism are examples of factors that can influence a person's willingness to seek help for mental health problems.
19. Schools should play a crucial role in creating a supportive environment, both online and offline, to mitigate the negative impact of social media on mental health.
20. Individuals should take responsibility for their own mental well-being.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
2. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
3. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
4. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
5. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
6.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
7. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
8. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
9. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
10. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
11. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
12. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
13. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
14. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
15. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
16. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
17. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
18. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
19. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
20. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
21. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
22. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
23. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
24. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
25. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
26. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
27. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
28. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
29. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
30. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.
31. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
32. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
33. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
34. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
35. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
36. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
37. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
38. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
39. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
40. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
41. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
42. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
43. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
44. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
45. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 9 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 9, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 9 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 9 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 9 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Solar Energy
2. Hydroelectric
3. Coal with CO2 Burial
4. Natural Gas
5. Geothermal Energy
6. Nuclear Energy
7. Coal
8. Wind
9. Biomass

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritized renewable and clean energy sources, while ranking coal and nuclear lower due to their risks.

36. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
37. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
38. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
39. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
40. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
41. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
42. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
43. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
44. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
45. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.

## [Example output]:

2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
2. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
3. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
4. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
5. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
6. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
7. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
8. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
9. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
10. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
11. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
12. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
13. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
14.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
15. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
16. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
17. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
18. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
19. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
20. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.
21. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
22. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
23. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
24. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
25. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
26. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
27. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
28. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
29. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
30. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
31. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
32. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
33. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
34. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
35. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
36. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
37. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
38. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
39. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
40. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
41. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
42. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
43. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
44. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
45. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 36 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- Using the Q Methodology, rate the statements following a Fixed Quasi-Normal Distribution between 1 and 11.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 36 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 36 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. through the fusion we will be able to exploit the potentials of the territory to improve the building-, commercial- handcraft- and agricoltural development.
2. the amalgamation will erease the local diversities
3. with the amalgamation there will be a deficit of democracy because the municipalities will be only consultive. The citizens will have no power
4. it is not possible to say yes or not to the amalgamation without knowing how it will be, how much will it cost and how it will be done.
5. the amalgamation will benefit the emplyees and the citizens. The emplyees will increase their competences through more trainings. Therefore the citizens will benefit of more specialized professionals.
6. the needs of the citizens are too different acros the municipalities. It will be too difficult for The amalgameted municipality to answer to everybody.
7. the fusion is the right answer to the limit of the union
8. the fusion is a leap in the unknown
9. in this days of crisis and changes at the european level, the amalgamation is necessary and opportune.
10. the fusion is too risky because is a oneway process
11. the consequence of the fusion is that either we will pay more than before or they will cut the services
12. there are not enoughf elements do decide in favor or against the fusion
13. the fusion benefits the bigger mnicipalities at the detriment of the smalles also with respect to the external fundings.
14. the fusion is a samll step to complete a path of amalgamation that started 20 years ago. The amalgamated municipality it is a realty in facts. How much do we have to wait still?
15. the amalgsmation will offer the possibility of save money by cutting the political costs and the burocracy costs and making the administration more efficient.
16. it is not yet clear how are they are going to amalgamate the contracts of the municipal clerks across the territory. things like these should be decided before the amalgamtion.
17. it is not necessary to be big to be good. The small municipalities can be better managed of the bigger and do more things. It is a matter of good administration.
18. the fusion is a decision that has already been taken and they are trying to imposing it top down. They are trying to sell the product "amalgamated municipality"
19. the fusion will change our relationship with the administration. The fusionwill move away the administration and the power from the local territory and centralizing it somwhere else
20. I would not like that the money of my taxes would be used in the municiplities next to mine
21. the new municipality will be politically more powerful in front of other municipalities like Bologna metropolitan. In this way our interests will be protected outside our municiplity.
22. the fusion is an innovative process that will make as an example to follow for italy and the rest of europe.
23. it is not worth to make the amalgamation in this time of reorganization with the metropolitan bologna
24. if the fusion will not be done, the single municipalities will not be capable of maintaining the current quality of the services.
25. the fusion seem to me another way to change everything to change nothing
26. we are misusing the fusion. The needs of the territory are not being respected and the valsmaoggia is being used as a labrat
27. with or without the amalgamation, the important thing that is at the practical level, nothing will change. For example the offices should stay where they are.
28. the fusion will bring the resources to make the intervention that our territory needs, like the bycicle paths or the public transport between the municipalities or the high school.
29. if the administration chose for the fusion it means that it is the right choice. This choice should be taken by the experts not the citizens
30. the fusion is necessary to lower the taxes
31. the union is a failure and a cost, because it absorbed just a very small part of the services and the money
32. the fusion is not the only solution to the issues of our territory but it is the more concrete
33. in this fusion there is no project, no vision and nos trategy. Things should be done in a very different way.
34. through the fusion we will be able to derogare il patto di stabilita' and therefore unblock some founds. The latter can be invested in the municipalities that are more in need 
35. the choice of the fusion is due to the wish of certain political parties to maintain the political dominance
36. the shift from the union to the fusion is a step to big which brings too many uncertainties. If things are done more gradually the change will be hurtless because people will be already used to it.

1. it is not possible to say yes or not to the amalgamation without knowing how it will be, how much will it cost and how it will be done.
2. it is not worth to make the amalgamation in this time of reorganization with the metropolitan bologna
3. through the fusion we will be able to derogare il patto di stabilita' and therefore unblock some founds. The latter can be invested in the municipalities that are more in need 
4. it is not yet clear how are they are going to amalgamate the contracts of the municipal clerks across the territory. things like these should be decided before the amalgamtion.
5. it is not necessary to be big to be good. The small municipalities can be better managed of the bigger and do more things. It is a matter of good administration.
6. if the administration chose for the fusion it means that it is the right choice. This choice should be taken by the experts not the citizens
7. in this days of crisis and changes at the european level, the amalgamation is necessary and opportune.
8. the amalgamation will benefit the emplyees and the citizens. The emplyees will increase their competences through more trainings. Therefore the citizens will benefit of more specialized professionals.
9. the amalgamation will erease the local diversities
10. the fusion will change our relationship with the administration. The fusionwill move away the administration and the power from the local territory and centralizing it somwhere else
11. we are misusing the fusion. The needs of the territory are not being respected and the valsmaoggia is being used as a labrat
12. the needs of the citizens are too different acros the municipalities. It will be too difficult for The amalgameted municipality to answer to everybody.
13. in this fusion there is no project, no vision and nos trategy. Things should be done in a very different way.
14. the fusion is too risky because is a oneway process
15. the fusion is an innovative process that will make as an example to follow for italy and the rest of europe.
16. the fusion is a samll step to complete a path of amalgamation that started 20 years ago. The amalgamated municipality it is a realty in facts. How much do we have to wait still?
17. with or without the amalgamation, the important thing that is at the practical level, nothing will change. For example the offices should stay where they are.
18. the fusion seem to me another way to change everything to change nothing
19. the fusion benefits the bigger mnicipalities at the detriment of the smalles also with respect to the external fundings.
20. the amalgsmation will offer the possibility of save money by cutting the political costs and the burocracy costs and making the administration more efficient.
21. the union is a failure and a cost, because it absorbed just a very small part of the services and the money
22. there are not enoughf elements do decide in favor or against the fusion
23. the fusion will bring the resources to make the intervention that our territory needs, like the bycicle paths or the public transport between the municipalities or the high school.
24. the fusion is a decision that has already been taken and they are trying to imposing it top down. They are trying to sell the product "amalgamated municipality"
25. the consequence of the fusion is that either we will pay more than before or they will cut the services
26. the fusion is the right answer to the limit of the union
27. if the fusion will not be done, the single municipalities will not be capable of maintaining the current quality of the services.
28. the new municipality will be politically more powerful in front of other municipalities like Bologna metropolitan. In this way our interests will be protected outside our municiplity.
29. the fusion is a leap in the unknown
30. with the amalgamation there will be a deficit of democracy because the municipalities will be only consultive. The citizens will have no power
31. the fusion is not the only solution to the issues of our territory but it is the more concrete
32. through the fusion we will be able to exploit the potentials of the territory to improve the building-, commercial- handcraft- and agricoltural development.
33. the shift from the union to the fusion is a step to big which brings too many uncertainties. If things are done more gradually the change will be hurtless because people will be already used to it.
34. I would not like that the money of my taxes would be used in the municiplities next to mine
35. the choice of the fusion is due to the wish of certain political parties to maintain the political dominance
36. the fusion is necessary to lower the taxes

1. There is no strong scientific evidence to suggest that the Great Barrier Reef is under threat from climate change.
2. Deep-pocketed green groups are willing to sacrifice our local economy for their own goals. 
3. I feel that future generations have been adequately considered in the management of the Great Barrier Reef.
4. Jobs and growth in Townsville should be prioritised over Great Barrier Reef protection.
5. Climate change is a threat, but the impacts are too distant for immediate concern.
6. The Great Barrier Reef underpins more direct and indirect jobs than mining does. 
7. Government should be doing more to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
8. There are more jobs to lose from Great Barrier Reef tourism than to be gained from the coal industry.
9. While job creation is important, we should prioritise industries that have less impact on the reef over those that have greater impact on the reef. 
10. There is no point throwing money at protecting the reef if our other actions contribute to its continuing decline.
11. Townsville is better off because of mining development.
12. We don't need to worry too much about environmental damage in the Great Barrier Reef because future generations will be better able to deal with these problems than we are.
13. It is not possible to conserve the reef over the long term without addressing climate change 
14. More scientific research is needed before we can say if climate change is a threat to the Great Barrier Reef.
15. If we are serious about maintaining and improving people's living standards in Townsville, we need to make the most out of coal exports.
16. Climate change impacts on the Great Barrier Reef aren't something I'm worried about.
17. If we don't take steps to protect the Great Barrier Reef future generations will miss out on the opportunity to experience the reef.
18. Government should provide funding support for industry, including mining projects such as the Adani mine.
19. Coal-generated electricity must be phased out if we are to avoid catastrophic impacts of global warming, including the loss of the Great Barrier Reef.
20. Mining development in Australia is a risk to the environment.
21. Each new Australian coal mine will contribute greenhouse emissions that exacerbate the risk of climate change, and impacts to the Reef.
22. We should prioritise protecting the environment in Townsville, even if it hurts our economy.
23. Australia's contribution to global greenhouse gas emissions is so small that we should wait for other countries to take action on climate change before we do. 
24. Protection of the Great Barrier Reef is worthwhile at whatever cost.
25. The Great Barrier Reef is a great asset for the economy of this region and we should prioritise protecting it.
26. Economic development associated with mining will provide more opportunities for future generations in North Queensland.
27. The first priority should be reducing other pressures on the reef (such as agricultural runoff or coastal development) so that the reef will be more resilient to climate change impacts. 
28. Short term development thinking will ultimately lead to longer term reef damage and economic impacts.
29. The mining industry provides thousands of jobs. Without it unemployment would have skyrocketed in regional Queensland.
30. We should prioritise economic development and job creation in Townsville over the environment. 
31. If future generations could have their say about the Great Barrier Reef, they would be less concerned about the environmental impacts than many people make out.
32. The negative publicity about climate change impacts on the reef has negatively affected the local tourism industry.
33. I think enough is being done to effectively manage the Great Barrier Reef.
34. Climate change is an immediate threat requiring action.
35. A few self-interested politicians and influential companies are prepared to sacrifice our well-being for their own short-term gain.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Anything that's been artificially created in a lab gives me Frankenstein vibes.
2. The use of gene editing for non-medical reasons reminds me of the Nazis during the Second World War.
3. Decisions about the use of genome editing are best left to the experts.
4. I think we should keep an open mind about new discoveries.
5. Each individual has a right to decide for themselves whether to undergo gene editing, as long as the changes cannot be passed on to future generations.
6. The idea that genome editing can make perfect people and societies is extremely dangerous.
7. If we open the box of genome editing we will not know where to draw the line.
8. We find strength when we face illness and adversity. It makes us who we are. 
9. Science and technology have too much control over our lives.
10. Genome editing is really cool science.
11. I am concerned that the use of human genome editing will advantage one group over another.
12. It's better to use genome editing to prevent a serious disease from happening rather than having to treat it with conventional medicine after it has occurred.
13. Parents want 'designer babies' with certain traits out of vanity.
14. Genome editing will be used for enhancement by wealthy people.
15. The idea of editing the human genome is scary.
16. As a society, we have an obligation to help strengthen coming generations by eradicating diseases.
17. There is nothing wrong with using genome editing to speed up evolution and help living things (including humans) adapt to challenges.
18. Parents and guardians have a right to edit the genes of their children before they are born.
19. It's a slippery slope from genome editing for medical reasons to using it for other reasons.
20. If genome editing is proven to be safe, then I see no reason to oppose it.
21. I have a more positive feeling about gene editing in humans than I do for animals or plants.
22. If human genome editing can be used to make changes to humans on demand for any reason, the future will be like a dystopian movie.
23. Genome editing in agriculture will have the biggest impact on people's health. 
24. The idea that people with genetic conditions might get cured in my lifetime is miraculous and incredible.
25. Interfering in people's genes is intervening a bit too far in human creation.
26. I think it would be amazing to have a choice in the way someone behaves.
27. I worry that something will go wrong with genome technology.
28. I'm worried that human genome editing will widen the gap between those who can afford it and those who can't.
29. Mitochondrial donation is a treatment more like an organ transplant, which doesn't really change the genetics of person.
30. I'm concerned that genome editing will lead to a reduction in genetic diversity.
31. Editing genes that will be inherited is problematic because it means making decisions for future people who don't exist yet. 
32. My cultural beliefs make me cautious about genome editing.
33. When you change someone's genes you are fundamentally changing who they are.
34. I don't think we know enough about genetic diseases or the long term consequences of genome editing
35. Genome editing technologies gives us power over human life itself.
36. I'm concerned that genome editing will be used as a quick techno-fix without actually dealing with real problems.
37. It is better to accept our genes the way they are than to tamper with things we don't understand.
38. I would be OK with having my own genome edited.
39. Suggesting genome editing will 'cure' disability diminishes those living with genetic conditions who need support.
40. I think it's okay to use genome editing to change someone's appearance.
41. My concern is that as we start to tinker with the human genome, we're going to accidentally introduce a whole host of other problems.
42. Beacause of our changing environments, I believe that future humans will need genome editing to survive.
43. I would consider using genome editing for my children to give them an advantage in life, so long as it's safe.
44. I believe we should remain as natural as possible but we should not shy away from furthering medicine and the chance to save lives.
45. If human genome editing is available then it should be available to everyone who needs it, not just those who can afford it.

2. Health insurance costs should be income-based to make them more affordable for lower-income individuals.
3. It is important to involve more private actors in healthcare (e.g., outsourcing administrative tasks in hospitals to specialized companies) to reduce costs.
4. Reducing the scope of mandatory health insurance coverage could help lower overall healthcare costs.
5. As health insurance premiums rise, more households require financial assistance, such as individual premium subsidies, to afford coverage.
6. A lack of financial support for preventive measures leads to higher healthcare costs in the long run.
7. A more centralized healthcare system, such as national hospital planning, would better organize and improve efficiency in healthcare.
8. Better coordination between primary care, hospitals, and specialists is essential for the effective treatment of chronic diseases.
9. More competition in mandatory health insurance, where insurers can offer alternative models, would promote innovation and efficiency in healthcare.
10. Higher tax deductions for medical expenses would help households manage healthcare costs more effectively.
11. Government control of drug prices would prevent pharmaceutical companies from charging excessive prices.
12. More competition among insurance providers would lead to lower prices and better services.
13. A more transparent healthcare system would help people understand costs and make better decisions.
14. The increasing demand for healthcare services is mainly due to an aging population that requires more medical care.
15. Reducing bureaucratic inefficiencies and simplifying administrative processes in healthcare could lead to significant cost savings.
16. Limiting the influence of private insurance companies in the Swiss healthcare system would help avoid higher costs without improving the quality of care.
17. Switzerland currently has a 'two-tier' healthcare system, where wealthier individuals receive better healthcare than others.
18. Less government regulation in health insurance would allow for more competitive pricing.
19. A public single-payer health insurance system would reduce administrative and marketing costs, making the healthcare system more affordable overall.
20. The Swiss healthcare system focuses too much on treating diseases rather than on disease prevention to improve public health.
21. Abolishing mandatory health insurance would reduce the financial burden on households.
22. Higher out-of-pocket payments would prevent excessive use of healthcare services.
23. The current system encourages excessive use of services once the deductible ('franchise') has been paid, leading to unnecessary treatments and higher overall costs.
24. Hospitals are more interested in maximizing their profits than in ensuring quality and access to healthcare.
